reviewText: I'd managed to sit (read: "force") my way though about the first 10 - 15 minutes of this nightmare (no, that was NOT meant as a "compliment") before I'd broken under the torture and screamed for "mercy"! So I'd never even gotten the chance to see how well (or not) this thing stacked up against the original classic, because it was proving itself to be nothing more than a putrid disjointed excuse to ride on the coattails of a cult film endeared by many and instead produced something that seemed to be little more than a libertine's wet dream that was over-saturated in unrestrained lasciviousness! A more appropriate title for this "film" (since it's not deserving of the label: "movie") could've just as well been: "Night of the Horny Toads."I'm extremely disappointed (and disgusted). If there was anything at all worthwhile about this waste of celluloid, I'll never become aware of it: this is just how much damage they've done! When you can get a man who can sit thorough even some of the most atrocious movies on record to turn you off & walk away feeling extremely cheated, that should be a clear sign that you have no business in the motion picture industry, whether it's as a writer, director, producer, or what-have-you! Auwe!
summary: What Exactly IS This? (other than raunchy garbage?)

reviewText: Angela to raise some funds organizes a huge party. Attending the party are 3 female friends of hers, a guy who's interested in one of the girls and his buddy, and a drug dealer who used to be the ex of one of the girls. The cops eventually arrive and shut down the party. When our group of kids try to leave, they find the gate locked. In looking for alternate exit they go the basement, where they find a bunch of skeletons. One bites Angela's finger.Now Angela turns into a demon who's after her friends. During spin the bottle she makes out with one of the guys who becomes a demon as well. He ends up having sex with one of the girls and that turns her into a demon. Angela literally chews of the face of another girl who now is a demon. That leaves 2 guys and a girl who have to deal with the 4 demons. One of the guys is played by an unrecognizable Edward Furlong. The girl is played by Monica Keena, who still doesn't show any skin but at least makes out with another girl. Keena should seriously consider suing her cosmetic butcher, who has ruined her face.The kids find shelter in a room that has protective writing scribbled on the walls. The house has some dark demonic history. 7 demons are needed but they only have before sunrise to achieve their goals. It's only a couple of hours more but Angela and her minions have some tricks up their sleeve as well.Night of the Demons is just what you expect and want from a remake of the classic 80s movie. It's sexy, funny, entertaining, gory, fun. Although more nudity wouldn't have hurt. It's good to see the lovely Shannon Elizabeth. The other girls are also attractive and very voluptuous. I'm glad to say that Gierasch has improved his direction over the years and in this movie he does an excellent job. His writing together with Jace Anderson is great, the dialog is natural for kids and the script overall is smart and fun. The special effects though aren't very convincing. Perhaps it's the lighting but there's no doubt that a mask is a mask. Still, a worthy and honorable remake.
summary: Fun movie in the spirit of the original

reviewText: Not a great horror film but better then I had heard it would be. I saw the original back in the day and I do not see why any one would care if they remade that hunk of trash. This to me is as good as the original in my mind.I think Shannon Elizabeth is a so so actress and fits the bill just fine as the party girl here, I even like her as a demon. Eddy Furlong has lost all ability to act and plays the drug dealer who ends up fighting for his chubby faced life. To be fair Edward Furlong is perfect for this role and is as good as any one else in the movie.I like the effects in the movie and think the make up, sound track and sets are good also. If you like bad horror with some nice looking Demons thrown in you may get a kick out of this "remake" but if your looking for a great horror film stay away.

reviewerName: Bartok Kinski "A casual stroll through the lu...
reviewText: Night of the Demons (2009) is worth watching for the T.S.O.L. "Code Blue" dance number alone.  T.S.O.L. is a California punk band which formed in 1979."Code Blue" (1981)I never got along with the girls at my schoolFilling me up with all their morals and their rulesThey'd pile all their problems on my headI'd rather go out and pluck the dead'Cause I can do what I want and they won't complainI wanna pluck I wanna pluck the deadMiddle of the night so silentlyI creep on over to the mortuaryLift up the casket and fiddle with the deadTheir cold blue flesh makes me turn redAside from that, Night of the Demons remake is your typical lacking, inarticulate, teenage horror film. More comical than scary, there are only two convincing scary moments, if that at all.The acting is almost universally consistent, but the story is actually quite weak-minded, brainless and asinine.  The demons' special make-up is notably gratifying, the sets are competent, and the special effects are good, but in fact, one should wonder why to watch Night of the Demons at all?Throw away characters (there is not one actor in this movie who is remotely likable),  the story was just oafish, and really incoherent demons (you're telling me 6 Demons couldn't get one blockheaded girl?).  The film seems to be caught between wanting to be a creepy horror feature and a numskulled cheesy, "funny horror".If judged by how the girls and demons were acting like thickheaded imbeciles, then avoid it.  It has a few scenes of peculiar demons, but not enough for me to recommend it. Edward Furlong acts paltry, looking a bit exhausted and frayed and still conveying no charisma.  All actors do pretty well though, but without any real magnetism.This is the type of movie made for a group of dumb high school horror geeks.Is it a unpleasant movie?  No, but it wasn't remarkable either.

reviewerName: ChibiNeko "Sooo many books, so little time!"
reviewText: I'll be upfront about this. If you're looking for this remake to be as good as the original, you'll be disappointed. If you're expecting it to be faithful to the original story, you'll also be disappointed. This movie has the basics of the story, but ultimately it seeks to be a different film all in itself- almost a remake in name only.Eighty years ago Evangeline Broussard threw a party that ended with six people missing, Broussard hanging herself, and the only witness being driven insane. Now years later Angela Feld is throwing her own party- one filled with drinking & debauchery. When her party is broken up by the police & only seven people remaining, a hidden room unleashes forces so evil that almost nothing can stop them once they've gotten started.I'll admit that part of me was a little disappointed in this film. After all, the original is my #1 favorite horror film of all time. While I didn't expect to like this as much as the original or for it to be as entertaining, I couldn't help but think that the film felt a little watered down from what it could have been. Not because of it being a remake, but because I think that they tried so hard to evoke the same feelings from the original film that this one didn't really get a chance to get a life of its own.That's not to say that this film is horrible & that you shouldn't watch it. There's some great touches to this film, most notably Shannon Elizabeth. You can really tell she put her heart into her role & had a blast making this movie. Also, when the movie's story started including their own versions of the sordid past of the house & why the demons were there, it really seemed to sparkle. I just wish that those elements had been a little more explored & played out. And the soundtrack? Easily the best part of the movie. This is the one area that didn't disappoint at all- the songs & music in this movie are fantastic. (Plus the cameo by Linnea Quigley was pretty funny.)The special effects & makeup for the demons were also great, but I have to admit that while there was enough here to like to keep me watching, there just wasn't enough here to ultimately wow me.Then there's the parts that just felt out of place. First off, the scariest thing in this movie was quite easily Edward Furlong & not on purpose. I don't mean to pick on the guy, but he looked terrible & he just seemed to shamble from scene to scene in this movie, not really ever trying. I wanted to like him in this movie, but the guy stuck out like a sore thumb. I also have to harp on the "tried too hard" aspect of the film again. When it came to remaking some of the most memorable scenes from the original (the lipstick scene), they just seemed to want to surpass the first film & honestly? It just felt a little flat & rushed- I wish they'd taken more time to draw it out. They kind of jumped into the lipstick scene with no real buildup to it. I really tried to view this as separate from the original & when the film was doing its own thing, it was great. When they tried to do stuff from the original film, that's when things just got a little tepid at times.Even so, this will make for a great video rental but I wouldn't recommend buying it until you've seen it first. I don't regret spending the money for a movie rental, but I don't know that I'd really want to own it. This is pretty much standard schlock horror fare, but it lacks that edge or punch to make it stand out from the hundreds of similarly themed horror movies out there. That's ultimately what will disappoint people the most- this isn't bad enough to have that "so bad it's good" thing going for it but isn't particularly great either. It's just strictly middle of the line.
summary: Not bad, not great, but not bad
Title: N/A

reviewText: A saucy bloody beginning to one, if not, the best horror film festival in north America, this years screamfest opens by bringing back some classic horror themes and putting them at the forefront. A contemporary take on the 1988 classic, this latest version albeit a remake, is a breath of fresh air from the all so common vampire and zombie pictures we've been forced to endure as of lately. There is nothing new in the concept but the execution is affirmatively clever in many ways. The usual party kids join forces at an old rented house where demons tend to dwell, trick and cause chaos to its rather clueless guests. Once connected to the reality of why they are really there, all hell breaks loose...no pun intended. Actress Shannon Elizabeth struts her stuff for all she's worth for a performance that should satisfy her followers and gain her a new crop of younger teenage male fans. A fresh addition to the cast is John F. Beach who's effectively charming performance forces the viewer to keep a watchful eye on him until his time is up. Maddie, played practically and intelligently by Monica Keenna's from Freddy vs Jason's saves the day with many unexpected turns towards the climactic finale. All in all, this is a pop corn movie for generation "X" ers who'd like to reminisce of horror from the good old days.
summary: a Fresh take in an era repleted w overdone zombie & vampire flicks

reviewText: There was a couple things I liked here. The tentacle armed demon, who is seen much too infrequently, and obviously inspired by Lovecraft. The skull-faced demon, who is quite creepy and effective. I also like the theme song by deathrock cult band 45 Grave. They've been around for a very long time, and this is their first new track in a long time. It's great to hear some new material, even if it's only one song.Let me get right to the point and say what I really want to say- buy the original 1987 film. It's got style, humor, it's well-written and the effects are done well on a limited budget. It's a classic with character and just a fun time. I equally recommend Part 2, from 1994, which was directed by Australian cult director Brian Trenchard Smith (Dead End Drive In, Turkey Shoot, etc). Part 2 is half sequel and half remake of part one, only with a bigger budget and more tongue stuck into it's bloody cheek.This new one, aside from what I mentioned in the first paragraph, has little going for it. Edward Furlong is on hand, trying hard to give a good performance and hold things together, but he seems to be wandering around not sure what he's doing or what is happening. There's a lot of trying-too-hard faux-sexiness and girl-girl touching blended with a lot of screaming and lights flashing and music blaring. It all adds up to nothing. It's boring. I say if you are going to remake a movie, do something really unique and different, or if not different, make it better in some way. But here they have not improved the original nor made it different in any interesting way. It fails and it's not scary. Boring. Skip it.
summary: A Pale Night of the Demons

reviewText: Guys and ghouls, you'd better sit down...or at least hold onto something because (cough, cough,) I actually enjoyed this movie!  A remake of Dario Argento's circa-1982 production, this Night of the Demons was enjoyable for this viewer.  Now, it's not gonna' win any Academy Awards, but it did entertain, didn't take itself seriously (at all), and still managed to be enjoyable.The premise is simple enough:  Halloween party at an old mansion in New Orleans is raided by the police, everybody leaves, except for 7 people, and then the fun starts.  Was it scary?  Well, not really--but in spots it was a little creepy.  Cheesy?  Honey, the cheese damned near dripped off the screen, but I like cheese every now and then.All in all, I was entertained.  This movie didn't necessarily go for the "gross-out" button, but there is one scene (and I won't give anything away) that made me realize I'll NEVER look at another tube of lipstick in the same way.  Creepy, tense, comical, and absurd all rolled into one!  But all in all, this remake is one of the better ones.  Bravo!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Remake it almost 25 years later.  Seriously. This is one of the worst movies i have ever seen.The original had lots of humor and some witty one-liners, a few scares, some fun effects, a boffo ending and and a great sense of what it was:  an 80's, low-budget B horror movie.  A couple of things that make a horror movie work: innocent victims in peril, characters you can tell apart, an effective setting and creepy lighting.  They're all missing here.  A creepy old mansion only looks creepy when it's not outfitted all over like a nightclub with LED lights, expensive decorations, and bartender with neon martini glasses.The cast, whew!  The original was a bunch of high school kid stereotypes and that works. All the girls (women, really as they all look about 30+) look like rejects from a suburban mall strip club:  lots of bad surgical enhancements and big hair.  Two of them even wear almost identical costumes which makes telling them apart even more impossible. The men, except Furlong, seem a bit better.  Furlong looks like he is in his mid-50's now and it's sad.  Characters talk his sexual prowess, but in real life it looks like his only love affair is with Vodka and Pilsbury biscuits.Anywho, no laughs, no scares, nothing.  And the place is lit with that greenish florescent that looks like the inside of a meat-packing facility.Movies like this make me wish the filmmakers had just taken the money and donated it to a food pantry.
summary: How do you make a horror film seem as good as Citizen Kane?

reviewText: The original Night of the Demons is perhaps one my most favorite horror movies of all time.  Of course, that being said, I had to see the modernized version for myself.  The new one has a couple of positives.  I really love the music and I don't know why, as far as I've seen, there wasn't a soundtrack put out for this movie.  In fact, I believe it kind of saves this movie from being a big zero.  I've actually looked up the soundtrack and have been trying to collect the songs from the various artists to make my own soundtrack for it.  I guess that tells you how well I love the music in this movie.  Additionally, it is visually appealing.  Lots of bright lights, color, costumes, mayhem - everything Halloween should be.  The demon effects are really cool - I especially like the demon that Angela turns into during the course of the movie.  Being an Edward Furlong fan, I was glad to see he had a place here.  However, the original is much, much better.  Shannon Elizabeth doesn't really do anything for me as an actress and the original Angela would have kicked her you-know-what.  You have glimpses of the original characters but they are not as expertly done.  I also enjoy the funeral home idea versus the new idea of a mansion in New Orleans.  And lets face it, nothing in this movie can top the dance that Angela does in the first one to "Stigmata Martyr".  For a built-on-cheese extravaganza, the original had a witchy quality that kind of made you shudder at times and question whether or not Angela was REALLY possessed.  In fact, the first Night of the Demons reminded me of the same feeling I had watching Evil Dead.  I think I cared about the characters in the original more than I cared about any of the characters in the new one.  How can you forgo such strong personalities as Stooge? I think Monica Keena was trying to modernize the Judy roll, but as goody goody as Judy was, she was much more loveable.  If you like Maxim type chics in tight costumes, swearing rampages constructed to fill in where strong personalities are lacking, and girl-on-girl action as well as some guy-on-girl action but nothing that interesting or new - then you might like this.  If you check it out for anything, be sure to pay attention to the music and the demon FX.  In my view the oldie is still the goodie.

reviewText: Roger Ebert wondered why some film makers try to remake films that were already good. He reasoned that film makers should try to remake films that could have been good. Here is such a case. The original of this film was a mid-level, direct to video "B" grade horror flick. Good enough idea I suppose but it had a no-name cast. The effects/make-up budget was good enough however to get the attention of the aficionados. So here is a movie ripe for a new approach.No such luck. Other than putting in more up-to-date effects and one name in the cast (Edward Furlong) not much happens here that hasn't already happened in the original. Yes, it's OK. You watch it without squirming but it's skin deep. There is no sub-text to help make it at all poignant, so the viewer sits by to see each of the cast members get turned into demons and wonder if any of them will make it out alive and, if so, which one will it be. It's been updated to appeal to the new twenty something crowd. Sluttier Halloween outfits, the (now seemingly obligatory) girl-on-girl action and some new music bring it up to date but don't further the premise.These demons need these seven people to allow them into our world where they can wreck havoc. But what of their plight? They're a loose knit bunch with no guidance from their leader, and give nothing to the audience to convey how desperate they are in the few hours they have. They're just a marauding bunch on the prowl.It's easy to see how Hollywood remakes any number of foreign films to make up for their near entire lack of originality, but when they go after stuff like this and cannot even bring it up a few notches, the thought of that is almost as scary as the movie itself. Unless you have to see every horror movie ever made I'd give this a pass.

reviewText: But its more laughable than serious. I remember watching the original when I was 14 or 15 and at that time, all the parents of teenagers thought anyone who listened to heavy metal music were devil worshipping satanists. So, living with my Christian grandmother, the possibility of demons wasn't Hollywood monsters but an absolute possibility. It gave me real nightmares that I would never admit to friends or family. This newer version just made me laugh. Nothing wrong with laughter in my opinion. It's not a movie I would watch with children however. There are some very strange things coming out of women's private areas that couldn't be explained to a child. Watch this version if u have seen the original just to see how far backwards Hollywood will go to shock their audiences instead of trying to scare them. It really is quite pathetic that these remakes are only being remade because no one has an original idea anymore. The French have far surpassed us in our own genre. Tsk,tsk Hollywood. Shame on you!
summary: It definitely has some unique gross out qualities

reviewText: I got my copy of this movie in the mail yesterday, and in ten seconds the dvd was in the player lol.  I loved the orginal, and i can cite the whole movie dialogue every time I watch it.Overall I think this is a good renter, and they did right with not releasing it in the movie theaters.They did have a lot more back story, but Im still trying to figure out how the blonde main character just happen to know more history on the house then angelia lol.1. Characters- I may be the only one, but why did they cast 3 blonde girls with two of them were dressing the same??I was getting them confused with each throughout the movie.2. The setup of the party made alot more sense then the orginal (why would a girl who the school misfit invite a group popular kids from school but who ACTUALLY showed up for it).  What was her motivation for those speific guest?This story plot flowed and made alot more sense when dotting the "Is" and crossing the "Ts" for the main cast members grouping, and everything in it was more realitics when it came to isolating the main characters. Agelia was wayyyy more socially accepted, which prob why in the orginal she had only 7 guest, (maybe she did invite alot of people, but those 7 were the only ones to actually come).3. The downfall for this movie was too much sitting and hiding and not enough action going on when the demons came into play.  I loved how the in the orginal, the characters were only stationary for a short time, before getting chased around the house by the demons after the first 30 minutes.  This version we didnt get to see ANY chase sequences, whereas the first was all about the chase sequences.4. The dance sequence was NOT EVEN CLOSE THE Mimi performance.  Her dance number was just creepy.5. LOVED THE GUEST APPEREANCE of Linnea Quigley!!!! Time wasnt too nice to her, but shes prob like 45 yrs old now.This movie kind of played like part 3.  The house setting had soo much potential to be creepy, but it wasnt.  There was a few jump scenes (I jumped 2 times).  I havent watched the special features, and the directore commentary yet, so maybe that will answer alot of questions of why they did things the way they did. I think remakes of movies like these doesnt work well because "Teens" now are not in a box, like in the 80s.  The teens in horror now just arent as fun to watch, memorable or likeable.The orginal Night of the Demons is the only horror film that I can think of where the cast REALLY MADE the movie.  I think those 8 characters in ANY MOVIE would be fun to watch lol.  Elizabeth did a great job for what she was given.  The kids in the fist movie was the funnest group of teens in any slasher movies EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
summary: Fair review from True Fan of orginal

reviewText: This is half the movie of the original. The blu ray looks good though. Still the first series of movies was alot better than this one. The first one in particular is a modern horror classic. This just doesn't have the same effect as that one. Someone needs to take those first three movies and do a blu ray set. This is a case of the remake not living up to the original but still being a decent above b movie budgeted affair. and this isn't a film like some c movies where noone has any experience , this was clearly done by pros and has decent actors. But even they can't save the tone of this one from being much flatter than the original. That movie was truly in your face good. However this does a great rock soundtrack , that has very little thrash music , which is a very good thing. Still it's worth a horror fans coin , only if you have bought the first version though. The picture is a good one though, like most recent blu rays they usually just shine in this format picture wise. There are a few extras , no deleted scenes though.
summary: average horror movie , good blu ray.

reviewText: just a letdown. edward furlong is in it, that should tell you something. he literally ruins the film with his acting and druggy look. the cheesy one liners are lame and the main star that everyone wants to see, Angela(shannon elisabeth) is hardly in the film. when you do see her, the make up is fantastic, but the shots are so quick, you barely get a glimpse of her. they downplayed her bigtime which is a huge mistake. the other demons had a bigger role than her. also its very tame compared to the original bigtime. the first film was pure b-movie grindhouse horror that was actually pretty scary because it was so ferocious. this is like pg-13 compared to that. what could have been a really cool remake was ruined by a bad choice in writing, director and casting. everyone is really good except furlong. shannon, monica, luther, diora all deserve better. i love remakes, but kevin tenney really should have voiced his input more as he was a producer on the film. see the original, its spookier and more trashy than this, plus angela is in that film alot more. she was so popular she did spawn 2 sequels thats how good she was, she became a horror icon. to push her to the side is just stupid and a letdown to the demons franchise. i hope someone does a better sequel, your sitting on horror gold if done right. Angela deserves better
summary: your supposed to out-do the original, not make it worse

reviewText: Story = gaggle of obnoxious young people attend a Halloween party at a haunted house & 99% get killed by demons. This version has been updated for ‘modern’ audiences so, in the early going a lugubrious Edward Furlong (who looks like he was wishing he was somewhere else) as ‘Colin’ a drug dealer goes to see a man about price increases – during the discussion some blonde woman is simulating oral sex on a very unattractive man with facial warts + an irritating voice – what is the point of this? The confused audience now think they’re watching a soft core porn movie but after most of the party guests are ejected by the police we now have a small group who are in big trouble – naturally a young lady needs to go to the bathroom (the loo) & when she looks in the mirror an arm bursts out & tries to grab her: she runs screaming out & gets her mates to return with her &, would you believe it, the mirror is intact. So now we’re back in horror mode: that means we have to have a homage (not a ripoff) of the old lipstick holder thru the nipple gag – the consequences of such an idiotic act are utterly disgusting. Next, a woman called Angela performs a lascivious act on a champagne bottle so the poor audience now think they’re back in soft core porn mode. Fear not – the demons (who look like refugees from a Dario Argento movie) start terminating the remaining dorks & when the sun rises & the lone surviving young lady emerges from the house the audience breathes a grateful sigh of relief that this dreadful mess is now over.
summary: Not a patch on the ‘80’s film of the same title

reviewText: This movie has alot of problems.Linnea Quigley only has a cameo, and you can barely see her face. You do get to see her bend over again and flash some little girls her panties.This is really not a remake. They took a few characters, and a few similar situations from the original, but the rest of the film is not even close to the original.  The producers evidently wanted to make money off of the first film, but came up with a dud.Third, Edward Furlog is badly miscast in this film. He is cast as a drug dealer with a romantic interest with the female lead, but there is no chemistry between them.Edward actually seems high himself during this film, even having dark circles from time to time around his eyes, and no one notices.Terrible shock value dialogue and supposed sex scenes. Right off the bat we a treated to a discussion on female grooming. What that has to do with anything is beyond me. Then there is the oral sex scene which was totally unnecessary.  Alot of the characters say through out the film that they need to go to the bathroom, but hardly anyone ever actually does.  One starts, but is interrupted.None of the characters have any depth. They are dull and interchangeable.  The girl who plays Amelia is just flat.The demons are not scary. In fact, the make up and special effects are pretty standard.The writers took too many liberties to actually claim this is a remake.AVOID
summary: Could have been, should have been...and wasn't
Title: N/A

reviewText: A remake of Night of the Demons?  Sure, why not.  Anyway, this new age take on Night of the Demons pretty much follows the same story structure: Angela (Shannon Elizabeth) is throwing a massive Halloween bash at a house with a demonic past and history.  After the cops bust the place up and Angela and a small group of her friends are trapped inside, all hell naturally breaks loose.  This remake of Night of the Demons doesn't offer up anything you haven't seen before, or any real surprises either, but it does feature a healthy amount of blood, gore, and gross out effects.  The babe factor (Shannon Elizabeth, Monica Keena, Diora Baird, and Bobbi Sue Luther) is great, and there are enough nods to the original film (including a cameo from the still sexy Linnea Quigley and a bloody recreation of the famous disappearing lipstick act) to make this worth checking out.  All in all, fan of the original or not, this remake of Night of the Demons is a worthwhile horror trek worth taking, as long as you don't expect too much out of it.

reviewText: I don't write reviews very often, but I saw this movie tonight and I want my $4 back from the rental store. This remake takes virtually everything that was memorable about the original (the creepy atmosphere, original death scenes, characters) and flushes it down the toliet. This movie is worse than (Rob Zombie's) Halloween II.... k it's pretty close. One the positive side it does have Shannon Elizabeth who always looks good and the first facial closeups of the demons are freaky. Everything else is a watered down version of your modern, straight to DVD horror flick. Now I understand why they postponed the release for so long, somehow it makes the originals seem like the godfather trilogy.
summary: WORST horror remake ever.... just wow

reviewText: <strong>Night of the Demons</strong> (Adam Gierasch, 2009)One is never quite sure what one is going to get when one comes into a movie penned by the creative team of Jace Anderson and Adam Gierasch. The two were instrumental in the resurrection of Tobe Hooper's career, writing the two best movies he'd made in decades (<em>Toolbox Murders</em> and <em>Mortuary</em>). On the other hand, they were also responsible for the abomination that was Dario Argento's <em>Mother of Tears</em>, the rise of Tibor Takacs as a Sci-Fi Channel Original Movie director, and <em>Spiders</em>. (If you've never seen <em>Spiders</em> and don't have a Lana Parrilla fetish, you're far better off.) And then there are the movies the two have written directed by Gierasch. I've now seen the first two. The first was 2008's <em>Autopsy</em>, an After Dark Horrorfest title that was not completely irredeemable. The second is 2009's <em>Night of the Demons</em>, which is.Plot: It's Halloween night, and Evangeline Broussard (<em>Autopsy</em>'s Tatyana Kanavka) is throwing her annual bash at the ancestral, and supposedly haunted, mansion that her family abandoned some sixty years ago after a night of horrible carnage. Fast-forward past a few badly-contrived pieces of "move the plot along", and after the party, seven people are left in the house: Angela; her trio of friends Maddie, Lily, and Suzanne (<em>Freddy vs. Jason</em>'s Monica Keena, <em>Wedding Crashers</em>' Diora Baird, and <em>Judy Moody and the not Bummer Summer</em>'s Bobbi Sue Luther, respectively); Maddie's drug-dealing ex Colin and his buddy Dex (<em>American History X</em>'s Edward Furlong and former Mighty Morphin' Power Ranger Michael Copon). And then there's Jason (<em>We All Fall Down</em>'s John F. Beach), who doesn't really fit in, so you know he's either a redshirt or a final girl. More silly plot maneuvering gets them stuck in the house overnight for the final piece of massive plot maneuvering: the seven of them are stuck in the house with seven demons who need to possess human beings in order to break free. Bet you never saw <em>that</em> coming, given the movie's title.I'm sure there are probably reasons you can find to talk yourself into watching this movie. (Oh, who am I kidding? Those reasons have the last names Keena, Baird, and Luther.) But I'm going to try and be like Jason, the helpful guy who doesn't quite fit in despite being friendly, and tell you: don't do it. Do NOT do it. It's like trying that drink with the fuzz on it to see if it's still good: you may end up drinking it, but you <em>will</em> regret it the next morning when you have the worst hangover ever. Bad acting, painfully stupid plot, characters who can barely manage to feed themselves... you get the idea. There is very little this movie does to redeem itself. Makes me wonder what the writers were thinking (and why they can't turn out more stuff as fun as <em>Mortuary</em>). *

reviewText: If ever there was a movie that needed Artie Johnson's German character (from the original Laugh-In) to grace the screen with a derisive "stinks!", this would be the one.  Not that Night of the Demons misses its mark on every level, if you get into women talking about whether or not they shave their vaginas, or talking about who would or wouldn't do someone, or if you get into seeing the guy characters cavort about stoned (they really don't have much to say in the movie) or bitch about the lousy day they are having--if this is the extent of your preference for being intellectually challenged with a paucity of  dialogue, then you were the one the writers and producers had in mind for being a potential viewer of this lackluster scare flick.  Keeping in mind the snotty retort "when was there ever not" that someone will inevitably level against this point about to be made, the sex scenes were too gratuitous.  Whereas the original version saw the characters merely wanting to get plastered in some old mansion, the new one has debauchery in mind from start to finish, and once you get past this not so high-browed commentary on the state of today's youth, you may get struck with the notion of how It seemed that the producers/director forgot that Night of the Demons was supposed to be a horror movie and not horror porn.  Either that or all of the actors, save for that toad-faced, croaky voiced Furlong, lobbied mightily to have their own little sex scenes.  Way to queer the anxiety build-up.  As for Shannon Elizabeth playing Angela, big deal!  I really didn't care one way or the other whether she played that character, whose purpose anyhow wasn't to grace the screen in her human form, but to cavort as an ugly, grotesque demon instead--and Ms. Elizabeth does that just fine with or without the demon makeup.The verdict:  casting/acting--pass the Tums, please.Demon/gore:  not too shabby.  Once you slogged through the first 45 minutes or so, the film picked up when the demons began to do their thing.  That gets a star.Soundtrack:  as many reviewers have already pointed out, very respectable!  That alone gets a star.Shock value of shocking scenes:  To quote Homer Simpson, "meh".  Whereas Linnea Quigley's breast impalement scene was truly freaky in the original version, the same scene recreated in this film felt like some kid playing dress up trying to imitate their mommy or something while saying "look what I can do too".  Oh, and look for Ms. Quigley's cameo in the beginning of the movie and enjoy the eeww.Now, that was a woman who could do sleaze and make it classy!

reviewText: I noticed several bad reviews on here, but I really enjoyed this movie.  I actually watched it first and then decided to check out the old '80s version, since so many people said that they liked it better.  I actually like this new version a little better. As much as I loved the Freddy movies, the high school kids dominated the '80s horror flicks.  It was nice to watch a film with the 20 to 30-something crowd. Also, I am a little biased because I love New Orleans. In my opinion, it is one of the most interesting cities in the world. Of course, this movie is current and the other is obviously set in the '80s, which is really the main difference. In addition, the party is more elaborate in this new version and there is a different back story concerning how the house became infested with demons. Anyway, I would suggest watching both movies and deciding for yourself. They were both entertaining. I now own both movies, and plan to watch them again.

reviewText: The Night Of The Demons remake is pretty much in the same vein as the 1988 original.  That is to say, it takes a pretty basic plot and goes right through the wall with it, giving us a sexy, monster-filled, bloody/gory shotgun blast of over-the-top horror that's wicked fun.After a grand Halloween party in an old rented-out mansion is shut down by the police for not having the proper permits to charge admission (as opposed to the first movie, which had a group of kids breaking into a funeral parlor), the remaining characters who avoided getting thrown out or who stayed behind to clean up (including party hostess/organizer Angela, played by Shannon Elizabeth) launch a smaller party of their own, but also end up discovering some weird, sinister stuff in the locked-up rooms of the old house.  Stuff that ends up unleashing demons originally conjured in the early part of the 20th century (there's quite a bit more backstory to this one than the first) who aim to possess seven mortals before the end of Halloween night and thus open the gates of Hell.The demonic possession isn't like in classics likeThe Exorcist (Extended Director's Cut)orThe Exorcism of Emily Rose - Unrated (Special Edition); think classics likeThe Evil Deadinstead, as the possessed mutate into fanged, clawed carnivorous horrors that pursue their prey like rabid banshees.Although the special effects are generally good, there are a couple of moments that stand out where they could have been better.  But this wasn't a mega-budgeted affair, and I think the glitches with a couple of the effects sequences have been given way too much weight.  Looking at similar small-ish budget fare like the already mentioned Evil Dead you could find glitches with some of the more ambitious special effects, but people don't let that ruin the whole movie.  90 percent of the effects are fine, and those that have trouble are not disastrously bad.  This incarnation of Night Of The Demons gives less focus to the cool, eerie atmosphere in parts of the original, going instead for an even more vicious, bloodier focus on the carnage.  That's not a bad thing.  A remake has to differentiate itself somehow, and it could have gone either more atmospheric and less gory, or gone the way it did.  Either would be fine, so long as it's not a carbon copy.  As mentioned, it's in the same vein as the first one, but there are those essential differences.  They're essential because, to me, a remake isn't supposed to replace the original (especially when the original is so good), it's supposed to exist as an alternate incarnation of the same idea and general theme.  I think Night Of The Demons succeeds in this.  Though not a horror-comedy per se, there is humor here, often of a giddy, deliberately over-the-top kind.  A couple of comedic attempts fall flat, but horror comedy is Very hard to pull off.  I think comparisons of this to Scream, though, are inaccurate.  Like the earlier Night Of The Demons and its sequels, it's way closer to, say, Evil Dead orRe-Animatorin regards to its humor.Overall, an awesome horror ride, way better than it seems to be getting credit for.

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: Perhaps 5 stars is a bit overrated for most viewers, but I liked what they did and tried to do. Scream Queen Linnea Quigley who made the original "Night of the Demons," the horror classic it has become, returns to us in her famous ballerina costume and gives us an encore bow. Three girls go to a Halloween Party at a haunted mansion. They enter the mansion with swagger music from Concrete Blonde's Vampire Song. The infamous lipstick scene, which made the first movie a classic, is re-enacted. The original sexy dance is replaced by Shannon Elizabeth deep throating a bottle and dancing with another girl. Unfortunately there is no love making in a coffin, a classic scene from the original. There is gratuitous sex and nudity and a British bad guy with the stereotypical name Nigel. It is not as good as the original. I will say that it is better than many of the horror remakes of this age (Halloween, Friday the 13th, Nightmare on Elm Street. Last House on the Left etc.). Personally I would have loved to have seen Linnea Quigley in a larger role. Simulated sex, simulated oral sex, nudity,the f-bomb, and some decent rave music. The plot is simple. We get a bunch of drunk kids in a haunted mansion. The cops stop the party. A core group stays behind, but then gets locked in. Eventually they make it to the basement and discover a secret room with skeletons. Angelina sticks her finger in one of the skeletons and gets bit. She becomes infected, (demon bites are apparently like zombie bites)and you know the rest.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I just pre-ordered my copy of this Horror/Halloween all-American cult-classic 80s remake, and I'm pretty darn excited about it. The original version of "Night of the Demons" is actually my FAVORITE horror movie to pop in the ol' DVD player during The Halloween Season.  With such a classicly fun and playful-- but also scary and weird, lol, Halloween plot... it's simply a "treat" to watch.  The plot of the movie is just pure, simple, kiddy, spooky, prankster fun.  There's a little twist to this remake, though... which is not too bad.It all starts when Miss Angela Feld decides to throw a harmless little Halloween bash at The Infamous Broussard Mansion in New Orleans.  Town ghost and haunted-demonic stories, scary tales of a tragic suicide, and creepy legends surround the history of this mansion galore.  Nobody would be caught "dead" in there. Right?  Wrong.  With Angela playing the fun-loving and mischievious hostess, the creative costumes, the classic kids' games, pranks, rockin' music, candy, junkfood, drinks, and all of the things we love so about this time of year... I mean, come on!!  This is definitely a Halloween party "to die for!!"Anywho, too bad a big chunk of the guest list gets busted by the cops, leaving Angela as well as a few of her friends completely alone, and locked in the mansion all night long to fend for themselves.  The Demons that possess this house are a little peeved and maybe just a little bit happy with these uninvited guests being there.  So things start to... well... get 'really weird.'  And all HELL begins to break loose!!  What have these kids gotten themselves into!?  What does this mansion want from them??  One by one the kids are taken into 'possession' by The Broussard Mansion.  After a few possessions take place here and there, the 'leftovers' realize that this mansion definitely has a life, and a secret plan of its own.  They find out that there's more to the story of this haunted house than they could have ever imagined.Who will survive and make it out of The Broussard Mansion alive, and be able to live to tell about it?  Who will be left for dead?  Who will decide to make this special mansion home-sweet-home, and actually become its 'loyal caretaker?'  HHhhhmmmmmmmm. So many questions and so many crazy things going on at one time throughout the night, as the demons and the possessed keep the party a hoppin,' ... So once again, the question is... Who will make it out of The Broussard Mansion Grounds ALIVE before its "Pearly Gates of Hell" decide to close in on them...??  PERMANENTLY.

reviewText: With the exception of The Crazies and Piranha 3D, 2010, has so far been a bad year for horror films. Some, hang in the balance between okay and forgettable, while most have been just plain bad. The Night of the Demons re-make is one of the few to keep me interested through 90 minutes plus. The cast is fun, and like the movie, don't take themselves too seriously. Aside from the basic plot, the movie tries to distance itself from the original (which is a good thing since it wasn't as good as people make it out to be). In short, this is basically a good movie you can watch again and again on Halloween.
summary: First good horror flick of the year!!!
